i have gone and registered <http://lexpop.co|lexpop.co>, <http://lexpopu.li|lexpopu.li>, etc.

so … <@U04N6235W> … i understand that in singapore, legal services have to be provided by those who hold a legal license. either an individual lawyer can be a vendor, or a law firm.

in the UK, since 2007, Alternative Business Structures have allowed law firms to be started and owned by commoners. <http://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/does_the_uk_know_something_we_dont_about_alternative_business_structures>

in Singapore, what organizational arrangements are possible for a hypothetical startup that wants to be able to say "yes" when somebody asks "hey, can you send me an NDA?"

attachments.title: Does the UK know something we don't about alternative business structures?
attachments.text: The debates in the U.S. go on: Should ethics rules blocking nonlawyer ownership of law firms be lifted? Is the current definition of unlicensed law practice harming rather than protecting
attachments.fallback: ABA Journal: Does the UK know something we don't about alternative business structures?

anyway, in the next week or so i want to set up a financial plan for the company, estimating the potential market size of each line of business.
<@U04SE0A8V|chiahli> has joined the channel
alexis: <http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/05/12/lawyers-with-lowest-pay-report-more-happiness/?src=me&_r=0>
Cheers! This is going into my so-you-want-to-do-law bundle of cautionary tales.
i suspect a big part of the problem is that lawyers are forcing themselves to do things that computers would do better.
attention to detail, analysis of large bodies of information, producing a set of documents that are internally consistent … all this should be automated.
there's a lot of legal work that's project management, too …

anyway, i think there's a huge opportunity to create an alternative law firm where most of the work is done by either computers or paralegals, and you just sit on top reviewing things and onboarding new clients.
i just generated 8 documents using legalese, configured to reflect the details of the deal … it took me 5 hours, but after the first 5 hours, actually generating the documents took me 5 minutes.
ooh, mad max came out already?

Oh certainly. But I think it's also because no one's wanted to or been able to go big enough to consolidate the collective intelligence (lawyers protect their precedents with rabid ferocity). I'm still thinking about the risk allocation issue we spoke about.
Anyway, leave for next week's been approved. Let me know when you want me to swing by!
great …
i want to meet with norvin and with bernard all together … you're off from 18 to 22, is that right?
gosh, that's the whole week off. nice.
why don't we meet maybe wednesday or thursday afternoon / evening. which would be easier for you?
Wednesday works best, but let me work around your schedules. I'm completely flexible next week.
ok, let's do wednesday afternoonish … i'll see if Norvin and his bunch can make it then.

A summary of allocation of legal research tasks:

1) Job: What modifications need to be made to the contracts such that it complies with the Singapore Securities and Futures Act? There is an "offer of securities" that needs to be clear of the requirements

2) Swathi: What can Legalese do to prevent itself from being sued by the end user/ minimise legal liability? Is Law Canvas' protection enough? What can be added? How much do insurance companies charge law firms for professional insurance?

3) Norvin: How can Legalese structure itself or its operations, to avoid S33 of the Legal Profession Act?
Thanks for being organized Norvin. I will set up an Asana thingy soon and park all my tasks there so we can avoid duplicating work. Stay tuned…
In the meantime, <https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Vttuonfu2BM>

Thanks for the rec!
I have added a few more books to the Legalese Shared folder – and to the list of sub tasks under Asana "Invite them to read some books."
If anybody here has read any of these books I would be keen to learn your opinion: should it stay on the list? How should we prioritize the reading? Which are more important than others?
Also, we need a movie night for you youngsters to catch up on Star Wars.
The story of the Despecialized Editions is a good lesson for us – editing, "value adding", the power of the crowd.

As you know, George Lucas is among that very rare subset of filmmakers who basically has unlimited ability to keep tweaking his past movies – whenever his FX studio has any downtime he puts them to work improving his past work.
This turned out to be a bad idea. Adding more animals to the background makes a desert planet less, not more, like a desert.
So: <http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/star-wars/35466/star-wars-fan-creates-despecialized-original-trilogy>

attachments.title: Star Wars: fan creates 'despecialized' original trilogy
attachments.text: You don't need us to tell you that George Lucas' continued tinkering with his Star Wars films hasn't won him too many added friends amongst fans of the series. It's now impossible to buy discs of the original Star Wars trilogy in their original forms (outside of the likes of eBay), following a cheap (in quality sense) DVD release in 2008.
attachments.fallback: Den of Geek: Star Wars: fan creates 'despecialized' original trilogy

text: fyi, i just finished the Holacracy book today … i really enjoyed it and am now keen to research which startups have successfully put Holacracy into practice.
Is Holacracy as suitable for startups as for mature companies?
Teal organisations seem similar to the application of holacracy..
there are case studies of organisations of up to 40,000 employees using the teal model.
i wonder if it'll work for a group of 4 people instead of 40,000.
Oops
I dunno.
I would have assumed that management overhead appears when there are more than 10 people, hence need an operating system for the company to work.
If there are just 4 people.. what can't slack do that holacracy can..
mmm. in the past, i've run into role conflicts even in startups as small as 6 people, so maybe it's worth building in the systems and habits from the ground up.
anyway, do look at the Holacracy book when you're done with the Laloux book.
there are a couple of original practices in there, which I would like to adopt.
I'm done with laloux already
What kind of role conflicts have you experienced?
junior staff highly committed to their vision of how things should be done, get upset when they don't have authority over that particular decision
other team members feeling the need to obtain consensus on every decision
some team members refusing to make a decision on their own, but referring every decision up to the founders
so, i think the concrete governance structures proposed by holacracy would be a net benefit even for a small team
also, i can see building a compensation app on top of the OS which would very nicely competent their Badge-Based Compensation app
it would be interesting to build a compensation model on top of the OS so that task allocation can be subject to market forces, whether for cash or tokens.
that would create a more permeable boundary between employees and upworkers
… and the notion of a traditional opensource volunteer.
so, just something to think about.
Percentages of revenue from a certain contract based on contribution?
Need something more concrete than counting lines I think
Groovy. I'll start reading the book.

could be something like that … basically, if some third party volunteer wants to dip in and do a major task, maybe they could … and they could get compensated for it … in cash, equity, or tokens that are convertible to either.
that way, the task list itself would have prices posted against each task, and anyone with a badge could go after any task available.
gamify all the way!

text: post reading holacracy: i like the distributed authority. i like they have an 'app store'. That's where the compensation app comes in.
agree that it's a benefit to have the system in from the beginning. There won't be legacy issues, historical baggages to deal with.
It feels very rule based though. Certain parts of it reminds me of the mccarthy's protocol.
but i guess: "Seek freedom and become captive of your desires. Seek discipline and find your liberty." - chapter 6, holacracy

attending the Singapore Legal Futures Conference – what questions should we ask?

i propose to ask about regulatory barriers to innovation:

*first,* regarding LPA. _Uber and AirBnb have recently gotten in trouble for operating in a regulated industry without a license. Some startups are starting to offer legal documents and legal advice on a commercial basis. Are they breaking the law?_

*second,* regarding LDP & LSRA. _Alternative Business Structures have been around for a couple years in the UK, and Singapore is thinking about setting up Legal Disciplinary Practices under the Legal Services Regulatory Authority. How much of a sure thing is this? When is this going to happen?_
i am taking notes in <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aLTAHvMlQdEmBdP4VIhcdhd1wB87GTnl1zfV6MaFTqY/edit#>

_potential to fuse with the first question_ 
the Minister of Law mentioned that many Singaporean law firms are already using overseas firms for "support work". what does "support work" entail? *what are the legal-related work than non-lawyers can do?*
i suspect that as long as the work product is reviewed and blessed by an SG lawyer, anything goes.
I am not terribly impressed by this Sam Muller guy from HiiL. Our tax dollars paid how much for this consultant to tell us nothing new?
"More and more devices are coming on the Internet. Societies are being revolutionized by Technology. Law will also be affected by change."
like, orly, wow
hahaha yes, but then again, perhaps he's just giving a legal tech 101 to those who have no clue at all
As a soothsayer, he is doing a good job. He can never be proven wrong
i would like to read the report though - we should ask for it: transparency heh

attachments.title: Even The Org Chart Is Now Made Of Software
attachments.text: Once upon a time, if someone asked how your company was organized, you’d give them an “org chart”  --  a page with lots of boxes on it. One box for the CEO, some lines to all the CEOs' direct reports, more from each person to her direct reports, and so on, until every person was duly… boxed. The problem is, reality makes a mess of that.

Sticking points on ownership and advice are still there
But encouraging that she's open to possibilities
What do you mean by approval?
A ministry exemption or legislation?
Which one is more likely and desirable?

That is a good question Job.

The official method of approval is subsidiary legislation by the Law Minister under s34(2) LPA

The unofficial method of approval is minlaw's tacit approval, which i think is what Axiomlaw has. The unknown determinant of risk to this approach, is how much soft power the Legal Industry Department has over AGC's Prosecution department

Official method is definitely desirable. Unofficial method is probably more likely (simpler)

We should ask for the official method to see Gloria's reaction. If somehow the Law Minister is not willing to give the approval officially that Minlaw will give tacitly, we can deduce more information

can anyone explain to me why academic papers don't include the date they were written?
i know the publishing journal gives the official date of publication

I think it has to do with the fact that publishers have somewhat restrictive copyright rules, and want you to post only the "pre-print" version on your website
often that version does not have the official footer with the date and everything

this is a prelim version of what happened at FLACOS 2010 - it was a workshop on formal languages and analysis of contract-oriented software:  <https://investigacion.uclm.es/documentos/fi_1289327707-FLACOS%2010%20-%20Visual%20Specification%20of%20Formal%20e-Contracts.pdf>

i gotta go soon but for now, advancingdragon, i would ask you to consider the question: how do we establish an "R12" isomorphism, and a formal->natural language generator, capable of expressing the example shown in <http://legalese.io/turing.html>

>The isomorphism principle (R12) was originally introduced in the context of legal text formalization [2], and the principle refers to the idea of a formal encoding that is in a one-to-one correspondence with the informal paper contract; one paragraph in the paper contract corresponds to a separate “component” in the formalization, and any dependencies between paragraphs in the paper contract are also present between the corresponding components in the formalization. The reason why the isomorphism principle is desirable is immediate: (local) changes in the paper contract correspond to (local) changes in the formalized contract (and vice versa), and a formal encoding which is reminiscent of the paper contract, should be easier for domain experts (i.e., lawyers) to maintain.
from <http://www.diku.dk/hjemmesider/ansatte/hvitved/publications/hvitved10flacosb.pdf>

Does anyone know of a way we can automatically create a list of the links and files we share on slack? 

I know Zapier allows the creation of folders and docs in Google drive for every starred message. Wondering if there are better alternatives to keep track of the files/ link shared so as to track information sharing (for current and future members) and to minimise duplication of effort / content. 

Idea is that this automatically consolidated list can then be organised manually later (or automatically if possible!) so we can point to it and say here's our master list of collective information, this is what we have read/shared on languages, competitors etc?
Editorial: message triggers for zapier can be based on a text string.
So I shall create a simple filter including all common file extensions as well as `http`.
Every message including a string matching these strings will be copied to a .txt file and posted to the appropriate folder.
Zapier does not support in-doc writing of such messages, so our reference will be a folder of .txts, not a single document.
Also, I am running into a problem where Zapier does not recognise shared folders.
I am guessing this is a permission problem.

text: as part of the Legalese project, we should put together a collection of resources that introduce the principles of computer science to refugees from law
i think this talk really helps bridge one tradition to another
calling computer science "computer science" is like calling architecture "blueprint science"
what we actually deal with is the stuff of thought.
Alan Kay thinks it's the science of processes
how to formalize processes of "things happening"
and thing about them
sure, algorithms.
if we can introspect and explicate, we can move thinking into machines. that was always the thesis of artificial intelligence. and today we do it one program at a time.

one could argue that computer science is the ultimate humanity. why? consider: humans may not be the only animal to use language; humans may not be the only animal to use tools; but humans are the only animal to use language as a tool.
we do that in computer science, we do that in poetry, and we do that in law.
so, to be a programmer is one of the peaks of what it means to be a human being.
that is rather conceited
you got it
the thought keeps me warm on my lonely friday nights
so annoying acquiring literature
